message_1: A manufacturing company produces bolts and it is known that the standard deviation of the length of a bolt is 0.5 cm. Assuming that the length of the bolts follows a normal distribution, what is the probability that a randomly selected bolt has a length between 6.1 cm and 6.6 cm?
message_2:
To find the probability that a randomly selected bolt has a length between 6.1 cm and 6.6 cm, we will use the Z-score formula and the standard normal distribution table.

First, we need to know the mean length of the bolts (μ). Let's assume the mean length is given as μ.

Z = (X - μ) / σ

Where Z is the Z-score, X is the length of the bolt, μ is the mean length, and σ is the standard deviation (0.5 cm).

We will calculate the Z-scores for both 6.1 cm and 6.6 cm.

Z1 = (6.1 - μ) / 0.5
Z2 = (6.6 - μ) / 0.5

Now, we will look up the Z-scores in the standard normal distribution table to find the probabilities.

P(Z1) = Probability of a bolt having a length less than or equal to 6.1 cm
P(Z2) = Probability of a bolt having a length less than or equal to 6.6 cm

The probability that a randomly selected bolt has a length between 6.1 cm and 6.6 cm is the difference between P(Z2) and P(Z1).

P(6.1 cm < X < 6.6 cm) = P(Z2) - P(Z1)

Without the mean length (μ), we cannot provide a numerical probability. If you provide the mean length, we can calculate the exact probability.
